articles.headline: Loans Lose All Value, and More
articles.snippet: In the latest bad news for the market for commercial mortgage-backed securities, a commercial real estate securitization trust disclosed losses of more than 100 percent on five loans.
articles.abstract: In the latest bad news for the market for commercial mortgage-backed securities, a commercial real estate securitization trust disclosed losses of more than 100 percent on five loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boscov’s, a regional chain of department stores based in Reading, Pa., has received an honor few companies get. Its name, like Google’s, has become a verb.

articles.headline: Group in U.S. Hoped for Big Payday in Offer to Help Qaddafi
articles.snippet: Confidential documents show how a colorful partnership of Americans saw lucrative possibilities in the power struggle that would end Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s erratic reign.
articles.abstract: Confidential documents show how a colorful partnership of Americans saw lucrative possibilities in the power struggle that would end Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s erratic reign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To a colorful group of Americans — the Washington terrorism expert, the veteran C.I.A. officer, the Republican operative, the Kansas City lawyer — the Libyan gambit last March looked like a rare business opportunity.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Penn Bullock

articles.headline: Utility Reform Eluding Japan After Nuclear Plant Disaster
articles.snippet: By weakening Tokyo Electric, reformers hope to break the linchpin of the collusion between business and government that keeps the country mired in stagnation.
articles.abstract: By weakening Tokyo Electric, reformers hope to break the linchpin of the collusion between business and government that keeps the country mired in stagnation.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a direct act of rebellion against Tokyo Electric Power Company, which owns the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant, the local government in Tokyo is moving swiftly to build a huge natural gas facility that would generate as much electricity as a nuclear reactor.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Low Expectations, and Trepidation, Over Meeting a Debt Deadline
articles.snippet: The special Congressional committee is unlikely to strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday, leaving investors, business leaders and consumers bracing for another blow to a fragile recovery.
articles.abstract: The special Congressional committee is unlikely to strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday, leaving investors, business leaders and consumers bracing for another blow to a fragile recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Expectations that the special Congressional committee will strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday’s deadline could not be much lower. The committee’s own members have played down the odds. Stock prices may already reflect the likelihood of a punt. And one of the major ratings agencies has said the lack of an agreement, by itself, will not result in a downgrade of government debt.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: European Rift on Bank’s Role in Debt Relief
articles.snippet: The financial stability of Europe has come down to one institution, the European Central Bank, which is under heavy pressure to rescue the euro.
articles.abstract: The financial stability of Europe has come down to one institution, the European Central Bank, which is under heavy pressure to rescue the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The financial stability of Europe has come down to one institution, the European Central Bank, which is now under heavy new pressure to rescue the euro — or possibly see it collapse.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: First Lady Takes On the Role of Staff Energizer
articles.snippet: After nearly three years of limiting her time in the public sphere, Michelle Obama is suddenly ubiquitous as motivator in chief.
articles.abstract: After nearly three years of limiting her time in the public sphere, Michelle Obama is suddenly ubiquitous as motivator in chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young campaign workers looked up from their pizza at Obama re-election headquarters in Chicago one evening last month to find an unexpected guest: the first lady of the United States, there to deliver a surprise pep talk.

articles.headline: Mormons’ Ad Campaign May Play Out on the ’12 Campaign Trail
articles.snippet: The multimillion dollar campaign features the personal stories of members who defy stereotyping.
articles.abstract: The multimillion dollar campaign features the personal stories of members who defy stereotyping.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Sunday worship in recent months, Mormon bishops around the country gathered their congregations for an unusual PowerPoint presentation to unveil the church’s latest strategy for overcoming what it calls its “perception problem.”

articles.headline: As Myanmar Eases Controls, U.S. Sees Diplomatic Opening
articles.snippet: New leaders have begun to relax Myanmar’s political system, court the opposition and fix relations with other powers, an opportunity the Obama administration has eagerly embraced.
articles.abstract: New leaders have begun to relax Myanmar’s political system, court the opposition and fix relations with other powers, an opportunity the Obama administration has eagerly embraced.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The long-isolated nation of Myanmar embarked on a potentially decisive shift in direction on Friday, as its main opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, agreed to rejoin the country’s political system and Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared to become the first secretary of state and highest-ranking American to visit the country in half a century.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Egypt Islamists Demand the End of Military Rule
articles.snippet: A rally in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Friday represented the beginning of a new battle between Egypt’s two most powerful political forces, the military and the once-outlawed Muslim Brotherhood.
articles.abstract: A rally in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Friday represented the beginning of a new battle between Egypt’s two most powerful political forces, the military and the once-outlawed Muslim Brotherhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Tens of thousands of Islamists jammed Tahrir Square on Friday, demanding the swift exit of Egypt’s interim military rulers in the most significant challenge to their authority since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak nine months ago.
